Introduction

Primary dysmenorrhea is a common gynecologic condition characterized by painful pelvic cramping that begins 1-2 days before the onset of menses and then resolves several days after the onset of bleeding.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



During menses, the endometrium produces and releases prostaglandins, which stimulate uterine contractions and promote endometrial sloughing.  Patients with primary dysmenorrhea have increased endometrial prostaglandin production, which causes uterine hypercontractility, hypertonicity, vasoconstriction, and resultant ischemia.  This causes the pain symptoms associated with the onset of menses.  The local release of inflammatory mediators and prostaglandins also affects the gastrointestinal system, resulting in associated diarrhea, nausea, and bloating.



Several factors can increase the likelihood of developing primary dysmenorrhea.  These include adolescence (the most common gynecologic issue in this population), tobacco use, and stress.

Clinical presentation



Patients with primary dysmenorrhea typically have the following classic symptoms:



  • Cramping, midline lower abdominal pain that begins 1-2 days prior to menses and stops 1-2 days after the onset of menses (due to uterine hypercontractility and hypertonicity)

  • Pain that can radiate to the lower back and thighs

  • Systemic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea (due to prostaglandin-induced stimulation of the gastrointestinal tract)

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of primary dysmenorrhea is mainly clinical and is based on history alone.  Patients who have a classic history of cramping, midline lower abdominal pain that begins 1-2 days prior to menses, with relief 1-2 days after the onset of menses, do not require a physical examination.  If a physical examination is performed, it is generally normal.



However, patients with any of the following clinical features should be evaluated for secondary causes of dysmenorrhea (eg, endometriosis, adenomyosis, uterine anomaly):



  • Symptom onset at age >25

  • Unilateral (nonmidline) pelvic pain

  • No systemic symptoms (eg, fatigue, nausea) during menses

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding (eg, intermenstrual bleeding, postcoital spotting)



Patients with a possible secondary cause of dysmenorrhea require a physical examination and pelvic ultrasonography.  Additional testing (eg, nucleic acid amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia) is dependent on risk factors and physical examination findings.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Laboratory tests are generally not necessary for the diagnosis of primary dysmenorrhea.  However, they may be considered if secondary causes are suspected:



  • Complete blood count

  • Urine pregnancy test

  • Nucleic acid amplification testing for infectious etiologies (eg, pelvic inflammatory disease)

  • FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels if symptoms are associated with abnormal uterine bleeding



Imaging studies, most commonly pelvic ultrasonography, are not routinely required but may be indicated to rule out secondary causes of dysmenorrhea.

Management



Management of primary dysmenorrhea is based on the degree of pain (determined by the effect on daily activities) and focuses on symptom relief.



Patients with mild symptoms often do not require treatment.  However, if patients would like pain relief, first-line treatment is with the following:



  • Nonpharmacologic methods:  Heat application, regular physical exercise, and stress-management techniques often help relieve pain.

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs):  NSAIDs reduce prostaglandin levels and alleviate pain.  They should be started 1-2 days prior to the onset of menses (when symptoms start) and continued until the pain resolves.



In patients who also desire contraception, treatment is with:



  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs):  OCPs reduce endometrial prostaglandin production by inhibiting both ovulation (eg, preventing pregnancy) and endometrial decidualization, leading to decreased menstrual blood loss, prostaglandin production, inflammation, and dysmenorrhea symptoms.

Prognosis



The prognosis for primary dysmenorrhea is generally good.  Symptoms typically improve with age, especially after childbirth.  Both NSAIDs and OCPs are effective for symptom control and improve the patient's quality of life.

Summary
